explanation:
- select: The loop controlling expression depends on os_status which is assigned from select. To decide if the do-while condition can vary at runtime we must know select's runtime semantics (return values, error behavior) because a compile-time invariant would require select to always yield the same result.
- errno: The controlling expression directly reads errno. errno is an external (macro/variable) whose runtime mutability and semantics (thread-local macro expansion, when it is set) are required to determine that the condition is not a compile-time invariant.
- EINTR, EAGAIN: These macros are used in the controlling expression (errno == EINTR || errno == EAGAIN). Knowing their definitions/values is needed to reason about the comparisons and whether they could make the expression invariant.
- clock_gettime: When msecs > 0 the code calls clock_gettime each loop iteration to recompute the timeout (tv). This changes the arguments passed to select across iterations; therefore clock_gettime semantics are required to show the loop condition can change at runtime (i.e., not a compile-time invariant).
- CLOCK_MONOTONIC: The clock ID passed to clock_gettime affects the time source used to recompute the timeout. Its semantics are needed to reason about whether successive iterations produce different time values and so change select's behavior.

These symbols are sufficient to assess whether the do-while controlling expression (os_status < 0 && (errno == EINTR || errno == EAGAIN)) is runtime-varying rather than an invariant.
